comments:
If you try to copy a folder from an SSH or FTP connection to Local or to another connection you get an error dialog showing Reason: "Index: 0, Size 0".

!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.jobs 4 2 2007-06-07 09:25:30.198
!MESSAGE An internal error occurred during: "Transfer Operation".
!STACK 0
java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException: Index: 0, Size: 0
	at java.util.ArrayList.RangeCheck(ArrayList.java:546)
	at java.util.ArrayList.get(ArrayList.java:321)
	at org.eclipse.rse.core.model.AbstractSystemResourceSet.get(AbstractSystemResourceSet.java:67)
	at org.eclipse.rse.internal.files.ui.view.SystemViewRemoteFileAdapter.validateDrop(SystemViewRemoteFileAdapter.java:1336)
	at org.eclipse.rse.internal.ui.view.SystemDNDTransferRunnable.transferRSEResources(SystemDNDTransferRunnable.java:197)
	at org.eclipse.rse.internal.ui.view.SystemDNDTransferRunnable.runInWorkspace(SystemDNDTransferRunnable.java:575)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.InternalWorkspaceJob.run(InternalWorkspaceJob.java:38)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:55)

-----------Enter bugs above this line-----------
TM 2.0RC2 Testing
installation : eclipse-SDK-3.3RC3
RSE install  : RSE 2.0 RC2
java.runtime : Sun 1.5.0_11-b03
os.name:     : Windows XP, Service Pack 2
------------------------------------------------
Could this be a duplicate of the supertransfer issue, bug #191367?

Using RC2 with supertransfer off copy and paste works except if you have an empty folder inside the folder you are copying.  Then that empty folder is not copied.

Folder Structure:
Folder --- One you are copying
--> Empty Folder  --> Will not be transfered
--> Another Folder
-------> with a file in it

This actually happens on dstore as well.
Yes, this is the archive transfer issue.  For non-dstore, we need to also check that there is archive support before using when the preference is true.

I'm going to keep this bug separate from bug #191367 because I see the problem here as trying to use super transfer on subsystems that don't support archive management.  The other defect can deal with the actual super-transfer problem, whereas this one will address the fact that we're trying to use it when it's not allowed.

Created an attachment (id=70684)
patch to not use super transfer when it's not applicable for the subsystem

Changes look good. Should the new method:

protected static boolean doSuperTransfer(IRemoteFileSubSystem subsystem)

perhaps be made private? The class is not an internal class, and I think having a protected method could be considered an API change.

I was thinking it might be something overrideable and since it's additional, it wouldn't break anything, but you're probably right - better to keep it minimal and not introduce something new.  I'll ammend the patch with private instead of protected.

Created an attachment (id=70699)
patch using private instead of protected for doSuperTransfer() method
I've committed the change for this.
Verified SSH/FTP do not use super transfer when it is enabled with RC4.
